ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lectures and live sections were used as well.
Recorded Lecture + Live discussion
also had discussion section live once a week
recorded lecture and live virtual section
Recorded lecture and live discussion section once a week
We had a once per week 50-minute section with a TA.
Recorded lecture twice a week, synchronous virtual discussion section once a week. Guest speakers for two synchronous class periods.
We also had weekly discussion sections.
Recorded lecture and live virtual discussion section
Combination of asynchronous lectures and synchronous weekly discussion section. There were also optional weekly lunch Q&As.
Synchronous discussion section once a week.
The course also had a live weekly (virtual) section.
Recorded lecture and in-person sections
This course was delivered in asynchronous, pre-recorded lectures accompanied by weekly virtual discussion sections.
We had two live lectures and live discussion and recorded lectures.
Recorded lecture with optional in person group discussions
Recorded lecture with live virtual discussion sections.
Live discussion section.
Live section

In addition to the recorded lectures, we had the option to attend group office hours and a longer lunch with Professor Debs! There were also a few synchronous meetings of the class when we had speakers.
Short recorded lecture + synchronous Q&A and discussion section
Synchronous office hours and discussion section
We had section every week which was virtual but synchronous, with two synchronous/live lecture meetings (along with the regular asynchronous lectures).
Recorded lecture, virtual section.
Recorded lecture, 2 live virtual lectures, and weekly discussion section
Tutorial
The course had pre-recorded lectures for the week but also met once a week for an optional Q+A session.  The discussion section was also online (live).
twice-weekly recorded lectures, live virtual weekly discussion section, and optional live virtual weekly Q&A session
Recorded lectures were supplemented by weekly class and small lunches hosted by the instructor.
Recorded lecture + live virtual section
In person section, recorded lecture, live q+a sessions with professor, discussion posts
Recorded lectures + virtual discussion section
Sections were synchronous, virtual conversations, as well as periodic synchronous guest speakers (all virtual).

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I understood the basics of the education system.

A great introduction to different educational practices, policies, experiences and structures. I think that a lot of the conversations and readings in this class pushed me challenge a lot of my thoughts and perspectives on the schooling system and how one can go about addressing inequities in it.

learned about the education system and its history, different pedagogies, as well as recent and long lasting controversies about education (teacher pay, teacher support, student impact, purpose of education, etc.)
I took away a broad overview of the range of topics covered in the EDST program and was able to dive into the topics that interested me.
I learned a lot about the foundations to education studies! (Ex. funding, teaching, history, different types of pedagogies, different philosophies of education).

Rural education, gifted and talented programs, segregation, alternative pedagogies, etc. Overview on American education system. Learned how to write a literature review. Developed creative skills in the final project. Course content was the best part of this class. (Also it was structured nicely and I never had to worry about my grade.)
I learned how to collect, model, and interpret government data for research. I also learned more about the U.S. educational system as well as education in other parts of the world.
I learned so much about the education system and how to think about education more critically.
I got a really good foundation of the scope of education, with a really critical lens that pointed to how complicated the landscape is.

This class was a broad survey of the different aspects of Education Studies. It was really interesting to see the different racial, ethnic, socioeconomic, and geographic implications on the kinds of educations students receive and the structural/institutional components which are either conducive or unfavorable for the learning of various communities.
I learned so much about education in this course. It is a broad overview but it is so necessary for people to take.
Broad introduction to the history of education and modern socio-political debates surrounding it. Exposure to foundational educational texts. Ability to think more practically about teaching.

This is a broad introductory survey to the field of education in the United States. It brings together the philosophical, historical, sociological, and practical sides to American education. You learn to analyze many different topics/issues within the field of education through each of these different lenses.
I learned about policy, history, philosophy, injustice, and so much more that I had never had the chance to learn about before in relation to education.
history of education, data visualization, exploration of alternative teaching styles
Great survey of the foundational concepts of education studies. Exactly as advertised.
I learned about education principles, such as history, policy, and present characteristics, such as the state of higher Ed.

I gained knowledge about how education works as a system and how that system intersects with other systems in society and the inequality that produces. Some skills I gained were improving my ability to write literature reviews and my ability to perform classroom observations.
Insight into the us education system.
How to be a good teacher, the major issues with the education system in the US, the education system in other places
I felt I developed the language to describe my own educational experience and was able to begin to unpack the privileges I had/didn't have as compared to my peers from other schools
Understanding basic elements and structure of the US education system (history, purpose, funding, curriculum, etc)

I learned a broad overview of the history of education in the United States, most notably the historical roots of problems plaguing the system and how teachers can work to change the system at the level of the classroom.
I learned about basic principles of education theory and the issues in the current United States education system.
Perspective to see education from American context

Learned about the purposes of education; differing systems and ideologies; and policies in theory and in practice. We took a look at real classrooms (virtually) and also took a look into our personal experiences with education through assignments and discussion section.
I learned to conduct a literature review for research purposes. I also learned to wrestle with the complicated nature of decision-making in education.
Reading about education, writing, performing classroom observations, writing literature review, and doing a creative project.

This is a great introduction to a variety of themes relating to US education. It offers a good framework that the beginning through three possible goals of education and then proceeds to show how things can be interpreted within or outside of these frameworks. Helpful for anyone interested in better understanding the problems and solutions for education policy and education in general

This course introduced many of the key issues and debates in education both throughout history and in the present day. I learned about the history of the education system in America as well as different theories on the purpose of education. I gained insight into the intricacies of the current education system and how policies are made and debated. I gained skills in data visualization, reading, and writing especially how to write a literature review. Taking this course amid COVID-19 was especially interesting because the pandemic has illuminated so many issues and gaps in the education system and this course allowed me to explore those topics and others in more depth.
Different types of schooling techniques, and different methodological approaches to studying and evaluating education.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The recorded lectures made it difficult to connect with the course and the materials discussed. However, the live sections allowed for more connection to the course.

The format that this course took given the pandemic was very successful-- it was clear that Dr. Debs and the TAs prioritized accessibility and our situations in order to provide spaces for critical and necessary conversations. The freedom offered in some of the assignments also helped so that students could focus on topics/areas that they were genuinely interest in using a format that can be creative.
i liked how professor debs offered audio lectures as well so we could take a walk while listening to the lectures
It was a great course that is able to cover a range of topics. One strength was that we were able to pick the topic that interested us to explore in our literature review.

Strengths: recorded lectures and virtual section, receptivity to student feedback, flexibility with deadlines (much appreciated!), creative liberty on final project 
Weaknesses: I felt that a lot of the reading was unnecessary since it was succinctly and nicely summarized each time during lecture

Amazing! I LOVED this course so much. It was structured so well and Dr. Debs is fantastic and very accessible. I loved the moment of calm and the focus on mental health throughout the semester. Also, the projects for this class were quite fun.

The recorded lectures didn't differ from the reading material. A lot was lost in this class because it was asynchronous. Dr. Debs seems like a fantastic person, but course engagement across the board was very low.

Strengths:
- course structure
- content
- understanding TF
Honestly no weaknesses. Reading load was big, but Dr. Debs adapted it and the fair assessments made up for it.

The readings were very interesting to engage with, and I was happy I could connect a lot of the readings to my own personal experiences with the educational system. The course also created a space for students to share their own experiences, and the discussion sections, being student-run, allowed me to take a lot away from not only the teaching assistant but also from other students. The only weakness of this course is that there is A LOT of reading, and it sometimes feels overwhelming to read 6-8 long chapters (ranging from 10 to 40 pages each) before the discussion section. I understand the importance of each reading, but I think it would help make the course more manageable if the amount of readings each week was cut down.

The readings tended to get heavy, but many were really insightful. I also think Dr. Debs did an incredible job of balancing the broadness of the course with including very relevant specific things by highlighting central themes.

I personally would have really benefitted from an synchronous lecture component more than an asynchronous lecture component. I also found it ironic that the Education Studies class was the class that had the most restrictive extension policy out of all of my classes during a global pandemic.
Strengths: the format of recorded lectures that could also be listened to was so great. I can't even think of any weaknesses, this class was truly phenomenal.

Recorded lectures were amazing - organization, engagement, and information. The course is careful to include stories of BIPOC and gives voice to issues that have previously been ignored in standard curricula. Dr. Debs and my TA treat students like human beings and care about our well-being

The texts were amazingsuper interesting, insightful, and engaging. Professor Debs is very friendly and has made every effort to recreate the course in a way that is flexible and forgiving with regard to covid. The assignments are interesting and very personally-relevant/meaningful. Rachel (TA) fostered an incredibly engaging discussion section where each person felt the trust and respect to share personal information and beliefs. As for what can be improved, I would only suggest that lectures would be modified so that they do less restating of the texts and more synthesis/bringing in different topics/perspectives/ideas.

I think one of the few weaknesses of this course was also a strength: Each week, we learned about a different facet of education. Because of this, we didn't get to go into depth in any one topic; however, this also meant we got to learn about a wide range of topics, and through that I've been able to figure out which I'm most passionate about.
The strengths were how interesting the material was and how passionate the teaching staff is, the weakness is how much reading there is.

The strengths of this course were the selection of readings, the accessibility of the professor, and choice of assignments. The biggest weakness I think was that the lessons we were learning about the best and most equitable ways to do education didn't feel implemented in the actual class structure and teaching style.

I think, while the recorded lectures were effective, it was hard to maintain accountability to watch them all. Often felt like I was choosing b/t readings or lectures 

A strength of this course was section, which was extremely helpful in getting different ideas and growing my own, especially if I couldn't do lecture

I felt that the course was remarkably thorough for a survey course, but often felt that the different weeks felt segmented  from each other- as such, I'd love to see more common threads traced through the multiple units.

The strengths were a positive learning environment, interesting concepts, and fun/engaging assignments. The weaknesses were I think mostly due to the virtual asynchronous style of the course; it was difficult to stay engaged at some points especially when there was a lot of reading for just two short lectures a week.

The biggest strength of this course were the assigned readings and responses. The main weakness of this course was the recorded lecture format because it was difficult to remain engaged with the course overall and I found myself relying solely on discussion sections for engagement.

Strengths: everything! The course is interesting and the classroom environment, despite it being online, produced engaging and thoughtful discussions about education. Weaknesses: the only weakness was that the recorded lectures made it more challenging to connect with the instructor, which just means you have to put more effort into doing that.
The course is extremely well-organized, and the instructor hosting weekly small lunches really served well to foster a sense of community.

Strengths: Recorded lectures were easy to follow and helped elucidate themes in the readings, live Q+A/lunchtime sessions helped us connect with the professor outside of lecture time, assignment formats were interesting, Dr Debs was an engaging lecturer, readings were almost always fascinating and relevant/important
Weaknesses: Discussion posts got unwieldy as people posted much longer posts than suggested (stronger clarification and guidelines on these would have helped), discussion sections could be a bit chaotic, assignment feedback was limited/not detailed

I think the fact that this is a survey course is both a strength and a weakness. It allows the course to cover a range of different issues that appeal to different people's interests but in doing so, attempts to cover so much material in just one semester and makes it difficult to dive into any one topic in-depth. The literature review and creative project however did allow us to write about a topic of our interest. Discussion section also allowed us to talk more about which parts of lecture/the readings interested us most. 

Another strength of this course is the sheer amount of material and helpful readings and supplemental links. Professor Debs is clearly knowledgeable and cares a lot about the class and her students' learning. Another strength is the students in the class and the diverse personal experiences and perspectives that everyone brings to section each week. One of the best parts of this class was learning from one another and teaching each other through our own educational experiences and backgrounds. Another strength is the personal essay which allowed me to reflect on my own education and how I think about and define the purpose of education. 

A weakness of the course is that it covers a lot of material and sometimes feels like it rushes through certain topics or leaves certain things out. But that is the reality of a survey course. Some of the readings also felt long and dense.

Strength is the way assignments were graded. I felt as if the grading style was structured in a way that facilitated growth rather than stress. In that way, I was able to learn a lot more content deeply than if priorities in grading were different.

Weakness is that discussions were not always deepening my understanding of the content.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The use of asynchronous lectures and synchronous discussion sections in addition to optional Q&A sessions was a great format! It would have helped if the Q&A sessions rotated so that people who had conflicts at that specific time could have gotten the chance to engage in more thoughtful discussions.
The course was well adjusted for COVID-19. Professor Debs really made sure the class was easily translatable to an online format.
the recorded lecture format promoted helpful flexibility and I also enjoyed  the in-person section. I also very much appreciated the flexibility with deadlines during the pandemic

the asychronous lectures were amazing. I loved that Dr. Debs also provided a podcast version of the lecture. I feel like the structure of this class really showed how much Dr. Debs cared and understood the insaneness of this pandemic.

Learning was great. The only downfall to the format was the lack of community among students since it was such a big class and my section had tons of people. However, the weekly lunches/office hours were probably helpful -- I was never able to attend because I had a standing appointment then.

Rather than attend an online lecture, the professor recorded the lectures ahead of time and gave students the option to watch or listen to them on their own time. The recorded lectures were very helpful and created a lot of flexibility for students who are already stressed out by other classes or by things outside of school. However, this made it a little more challenging to engage with the course since I often felt isolated from the professor. The professor does offer lunch time office hours, but this often interfered with my other courses, preventing me from ever attending them.

The recorded lectures were super helpful, as they were very flexible. For the most part, there seemed to be consideration for the time we are in. I also appreciated the openness to student feedback and critique.

I think the asynchronous component was really helpful when scheduling otherwise was hectic. I think everyone in the education studies community was very willing to create the kind of atmosphere where people could get to know each other in whatever capacity they are able to. However, I do think the restrictive extension policy was ironic and insensitive.

The audio recordings and moments of calm were so appreciated. Dr. Debs made every effort to organize everything in modules and make learning easier. The best class by far this semester in terms of adapting to the online format.
Structuring meditation time into the recorded lectures! Very organized powerpoints in the lectures! 50 minute discussion section instead of an obnoxiously long one!

Lectures were pre-recorded and shorter, which was so so nice. Dr. Debs and the TAs were very understanding about giving extensions and provided lots of guidance on assignments. The camera optional policy in section was nice and I also liked the live office hours that Debs hosted, which enabled students to meet other students.

Professor Debs did a great job of making this course accessible to students in all time zones while also hosting many forms of office hours for students who wanted to meet in real time. The discussion sections were very nice supplements to the pre-recorded lectures as well.

It was really great that the prerecorded lectures were rarely over the original allotted amount of time for the class. It felt like Dr. Debs and the TFs were very respectful of our time and other commitments this semester.

I thought the the moment of calms were really good and helped to humanize it. Something that I thought could be improved is maybe if we listened more to podcasts than read, as we were doing so much reading already.
The COVID adaptations worked really well, including some of the deadline flexibility, recorded lectures, required section, and the option to show up for live office hours/Q&A sessions

The instructor was very understanding about deadlines, which was helpful. I though breakout rooms were used well in discussion section (I had Rachel), especially how they were used at the beginning of the class to get people's brains active. I felt neither here nor there about the lectures being asynchronous, but I did find them harder to engage with. I also really enjoyed the occasional live virtual events towards the end of the course.
recorded lecture accompanied by short quizzes would have helped, for accountability
The minute of calm was unexpectedly nice. I liked the lecture formats and the modules were well organized.

I felt that the class was very flexible and offered a great mix of support and individual pacing, but sometimes I wished I had more opportunity to connect with peers who couldn't make it to the office hours/lunches.

All of them were very successfulDr. Debs cares deeply about the well-being of her students and does a lot to ensure we get the most out of the course in a way that doesn't overwhelm us. The short lectures were great and really easy to digest, almost like listening to story or podcast. The live session with Dr.Debs were wonderful opportunities to get to talk with her topics she knows so much about and have honest conversations about some difficult topics.
It was challenging to stay engaged with the prerecorded lectures although I did appreciate the flexibility.

The recorded lecture format was a point of difficulty for me, but it was helpful when the professor changed the view so that their face was a part of the screen. I thought that virtual discussion sections, especially the ones that were structured, went well and were helpful in understanding course material.

Success: recorded lectures allowed people to view and review lectures at any time. Possible improvement: I think it would have been convenient for students to have access to a script of the recorded lectures (other courses have the transcript of the speech from the video on canvas and this allows students to search the videos for keywords, definitions, examples, etc.)
The small lunches and moments of calm were terrific.

Asynchronous lectures and live section plus the live Q&A and thursday lunches with the professor were a really great balance of everything. There were opportunities to get to know the professor outside of lecture, participate in discussion, but also the lectures were asynchronous so that we could watch or listen to lecture in our own time.

This was the best organised Canvas class page I've had, all Professors should take a look at this page for inspiration. The readings, lectures, discussion section posts and more were organised by week so it was easy to locate everything each week. Dr Debs was also the most readily available professor I have had in an online class, providing many opportunities to talk with her and ask questions

The recorded lectures were helpful because it allowed me to go back and rewatch parts of lectures to better understand the material. It required more self-motivation to stay on top of lectures and stay on track, though. Virtual discussion section seemed to work well. Our TF helped create a welcoming and supportive environment where people could speak up and participate. Having breakout rooms sometimes in section was also helpful because it allowed us to get to know each other better and talk in smaller group settings.

Professor Debs also hosted a weekly Q&A session that I think was helpful and allowed students to ask specific questions and explore topics more in-depth in smaller groups.

A huge help for me was that Dr. Debs put up audio files of lectures in addition to slides & video recording. Not only did it give me a break from the abundance of screens we had this COVID semester, but it also allowed me to engage the kinesthetic learner in me, as Id move my body on walks while engaging with the information and retained the info more than the regular classroom.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you are interested in learning anything about education systems, pedagogies, or simply want to understand your own educational path, I suggest this class.

Absolutely! I would recommend it for anyone who slightly interested because the breadth of the topics covered allows for students to focus in on topics that closely relate to their interests without sacrificing the  wealth of topics covered. Dr. Debs is a great instructor as well and shares great advice and knowledge from her extensive expertise and field of research.
yes, i think every student could relate to something that's taught in this course and learn something new
If you are interested in education, I would!
Yes!

YES! take this course if you have any interest in education whatsoever. I learned so much from this class about education and I got to read so many amazing books and articles and really look at my education from a different perspective
Yes. Every Yale student should take this class. In fact, every American should take this class. We learn very important concepts about the US education system, and Dr. Debs is a fabulous resource.

I would definitely recommend this course. It's a class that makes you think critically about your educational experience and how education in general should be improved for the next generation of students.
Yes! Even if you are not planning to go into education, I think the information is something that everyone should know.

Yes! If you are interested in education, this is definitely a helpful class to begin processing the complexity of the education system and your experiences. It's incredibly relevant and applicable! I also think the assignments (i.e lit review, classroom observation) served as helpful exposure to what working in education could entail.
Yes.
Yes!

Yes! If you are at all interested in understanding the education system in America, this course is an excellent place to start. The texts are all amazingsuper interesting and different. You get the opportunity to critically reflect on your educational experiences and what those experiences should be.

Absolutely I would, but with some caveats: First, you must be willing to move from topic to topic quickly; second, you must be somewhat interested in education, because there are a lot of readings and you have to motivate yourself to do them; and third, you have to have an open mind and be a good listener--people in section always have great things to share, but you must be attentive to them.
Yes, this is a great foundational course if you're interested in any aspect of Education
Yes, I would! Definitely take this course if you are interested in education. It has really changed the way I see education and myself as a student.

I would highly recommend this class to another student. The readings are really interesting, but not overwhelming, and you can understand the lectures even if you miss a few of the readings. Professor Debs is really understanding and seemed to be genuinely interested in engaging with students. My biggest complaint though was that we were learning about education, but the class didn't feel very different from my other courses. I don't know that the course was set up for much of the deeper or higher impact learning we were reading about. The classroom hierarchy was still very present and grading still took a prominent place in feedback, which was all a little disappointing.
Yes this is a great intro to education.
Yes! regardless of whether or not you're into education, I saw this information, as an econ major, widely applicable
Yes! If youre interested in education, this is a great way to see what the different areas within education are.

Yes! I think that the self reflection (and reflection in general ) that is developed throughout the class is imperative for students to understand their role in the educational sphere that they interact with on a daily basis.
Yes! Professor Debs is super sweet and supportive of everyone's education related interests!

I would recommend this course to a student interested in teaching or entering the field of education, especially if they are doing the EDST certificate or pathway. Even if they are not, it is a low stress course and Professor Debs is very relaxing and kind.

The material learned from this course is very valuable and interesting, especially if you want to learn how education may affect other aspects of society. The professor was very kind and discussion was great. However, it can be hard to remain engaged with the course as it stands, so what you get out of the course is very dependent on what you put into it.

I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in learning more about education policy, teaching, or the education system as a whole. The course is informative and what you learn can be applied to your education experience no matter where you are from or what type of schooling you received.
Yes. This course reveals much about how education has evolved in the U.S. and prepares participants to think more carefully about the kinds of education "reform" we want to support.

Yes if you want to learn a broad overview of a lot of topics in education (like an introduction) and then see if you want to take more courses that are more specific education topics. I will say you get out of the course what you put in. And If you plan to be an education studies scholar, this course is required and crucial for the program.

I would recommend this for any students interested in working in education whether as a teacher, policymaker or more. I would also recommend this to anyone who is frustrated with any aspect of education as it offers many insights into why this is the case or what can be done about it!!

Yes! If you want an overview of education and how the system works and operates today and in history, then definitely take this course. If you're interested in education, teaching as a career, or just reflecting on your own education, this course is for you. Taking this as a senior especially allowed me to look back and think about the purpose and value of my education. Section depends on your TF, but lectures are informative and because they were recorded, in-person would probably be even more engaging.
Yes
